segments.text: Morgan , can I ask you a question ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: I was just wondering if many Chinese people take their leftover food home from a restaurant .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: in most cities in China , doggie bags are quite uncommon .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: what happen to all the leftover food ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: it usually goes to the dump .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: that seems like an awful waste ! Why don't people order fewer dishes so that they don't have to throw so much away at the end of the meal ?
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: ordering a lot of food at restaurants is just a tradition in China . You know , in the past , people could not afford to eat out like they can today .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: I guess that makes sense . I just think it would make more sense to take the leftovers home .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: well , if you want , you can take the leftovers home .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: no , that's OK . You know what they say when in Rome ...
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: I was impressed that you tried the pig's feet . I heard that many foreigners don't like to eat them .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: many people in my generation don't eat pig's feet , but my parents grew up eating them , so I think they are OK .
segments.speaker: S1

segments.text: did you like them ? You could take the last one home with you .
segments.speaker: S2

segments.text: that's OK . I'll try anything once , but sometimes , once is enough !
segments.speaker: S1
